Award.AwardTitle: Genetic Heritability and Spatiotemporal Transcriptional Mapping of the Vocal Learning Process Using a Minimal Song-training Paradigm
Award.AbstractNarration:
Thierry Lints
Proposal# 0951277
Genetic Heritability and Spatiotemporal Transcriptional Mapping of the Vocal Learning Process Using a Minimal Song-training Paradigm

The vocal learning process forms the foundation of infant speech development and language. This process is best understood at the molecular and electrophysiological level in songbirds, particularly the zebra finch. During their formative first months, juvenile male zebra finches learn to produce a complex stereotyped song, typically based on their father?s song. Using computer-based training of juvenile zebra finch males to song playbacks, the proposed research sets out to provide a systematic exploration of the opening moments of the vocal imitation process. As a memory of the tutor song model can be acquired during the first training session, the underlying neural events that initiate vocal imitation can be time locked to a single morning of juvenile life. This song training approach may illuminate the fundamental molecular processes that guide developmental learning and constrain it as a consequence of previous experiences or maturational age. Whole-brain 3-dimensional reconstructions of dynamic gene expression patterns will reveal how neuronal activity and experience-dependent neural plasticity rapidly evolve over the first few days of vocal learning. This research serves as an excellent vehicle to train undergraduate and graduate students in the quantitative analysis of behavior, molecular biology, brain image analysis and nervous system structure and function. Moreover, a collaborative effort is ongoing to introduce zebra finches into high school classrooms and develop a web-based virtual learning environment involving live-feeds from birds undergoing training in the lab, providing school students the opportunity to work on real life science problems using quantitative approaches to the acoustic analysis of birdsong.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project are: 1) To first define a behavioral training paradigm for vocal learning in the juvenile male zebra finch, such that acquisition of the memory of adult male tutor song (also known as the 'template') can be unequivocally constrained to a window of just a few hours of juvenile life. This timelocking of template acquisition represents a crucial step in identifying the molecular, cellular and electrophysiological mechanisms encoding this detailed memory of the specific acoustic (or motoric) properties of the tutor song. 2) To utilize such a training paradigm, involving minimal exposure to tutor song, to examine which regions of the brain may be specifically engaged in the process of template acquisition and refinement. In order to take a spatially unbiased approach to examining brain activity in birds, this second goal involved developing a data processing pipeline that would allow the expression patterns of genes activated by neuronal depolarization to be analyzed throughout reconstructed whole brain volumes using statistical parametric mapping tools.

We published several important results from our investigations.  Firstly, our data clearly indicate that rapid vocal changes occur on the day of training, before normal night sleep. This runs contrary to the generally accepted idea (based on electrophysiological and behavioral data from a very small number of birds) that neural activity changes occuring during the first post-training night sleep represent an essential prerequisite step before the onset of the first vocal changes occuring on the day after tutor song exposure. Moreover, our data demonstrate a positive correlation between the extent of vocal change on the day of training and future imitative success. This has impotant practical implications for the seach for neurons encoding the template, as we would therefore predict that the response properties of neurons potentially encoding the template should change over the course of the day of training, and in a way that is correlated with the degree of rapid same-day vocal change. We also report experiments that represent a first step toward teasingapart how auditory and visual sensory inputs might interact during minimal tutoring. Although preliminary, this finding suggested the possibility that, for younger birds, visual input might interfere withauditory acquisition of the template. Much more work needs to be done to explore how different sensory modalities interact during the acquisition ofcomplex learned social communication signals, such as birdsong. These results highlight the utility of our minimal training paradigm in exploring such questions.


With respect to the second aim of our proposal, we made significant
progress in refining the methods used for registration of reconstructed highresolution brain volumes into a normalized space, and this has allowed us to make some interesting observations regarding the recruitment of rather small neural territories during the process of template encoding and/or updating. It is important to note that many researchers in the birdsong field think that the 'template' is stored in regions of the auditory forebrain that process complex acoustic features of song. However, we believe the case for this is still not watertight and that, therefore, there is potentially value in our efforts to apply a spatially unbiased approached to the question of template localization.

We expect that our research will provide significant insights into the molecular control of vocal development. This developmental learning process is intimately tied to the maturation of the brain, and so on a more general level, our experiments may shed light on cognitive maturation in the juvenile brain.
